variant.question: The following type of icing can be expected in cirrus clouds:

options.text: No icing to be expected.
Light icing can sometimes occur.
Light icing only.
Moderate icing only.

variant.question: Snow grains:

options.text: fall from stratus or supercooled fog.
are typically formed inside a CB, where they are being tossed up and down while growing to such size that they could no longer be supported in the updraught.
are mainly formed inside altostratus and nimbostratus.
are normally transparent.

variant.question: The presence of ice pellets at a height of 8 000 ft indicates

options.text: freezing rain at heights above 8 000 ft.
the approach of an area with thunderstorms.
a trough at great height.
hail during the next part of the flight.

variant.question:
Which of the following options is the best recommendation to avoid dangerous icing for a pilot of an aircraft, in temperate latitudes, if the planned route of the flight would take the aircraft along a warm front on the cold-air side?
Consider the following additional information; the ceiling of the Nimbostratus clouds is at 1400 ft AGL, the freezing level on the cold-air side is at 1000 ft AGL, on the warm-air side at 2000 ft. The front is quite weak and the width of the precipitation band is 20 NM. The aircraft is equipped with serviceable anti-icing and de-icing systems. The pilot does NOT have a valid instrument rating, therefore the flight has to be made in VMC.

options.text: Traverse the warm front perpendicular to its direction of movement and fly below the freezing level.
Fly below the clouds and above the freezing level on the cold-air side because any precipitation encountered in this area will NOT adhere to the airframe.
Stay at least 5 NM ahead of the front clear of the clouds and don't cross the front.
Fly on the cold-air side of the front just below the altitude of the freezing level of the air on the warm side.

variant.question: Where are you most likely to encounter little or no precipitation?

options.text: Over flat terrain in the centre of high pressure area in stable atmosphere.
Frontal zone.
In an occlusion.
On the windward side of the alps in a foehn situation.

variant.question: How does a pilot react to heavy freezing rain at 2000 ft/AGL, when he is unable to deice, nor land?

options.text: He turns back before the aircraft loses manoeuvrability.
He ascends to the cold air layer above.
He continues to fly at the same altitude.
He descends to the warm air layer below.

variant.question: The highest concentrations of ice crystals are most likely to occur within the...

options.text: anvil overhead the core of an oceanic mesoscale convective system.
downdraughts associated with a large tropical cyclone.
freezing level surrounding the central uplift core of a convective storm.
spreading cirrus from the top of an active warm front.

variant.question: Where on the aircraft does ice crystal icing (ICI) form?

options.text: Inside the jet engine.
On the propellor tips.
On the leading edge of the wings.
On protruding surfaces, such as the pitot tube and antennas.

variant.question: Where on the aircraft does ice crystal icing (ICI) form?

options.text: Inside the jet engine
On propeller tips
On protruding surfaces ,such as the pitot tubes and antennas
On the leading edge of the wings

variant.question: How should Ice Crystal Icing (ICI) be avoided?

options.text: Locate the main rain cell and then fly upwind.
Locate the main rain cell and fly downwind.
Fly through the storm.
Locate the main rain cell and fly above.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 An aircraft is planned to fly from Nairobi ('N', approximately 1°S, 37°E) to Manila ('M', approximately 15°N,121°E). Assuming the track follows the straight line depicted on the chart, and the cruising FL increases from initially FL370 to FL490 halfway through the flight, where along the route is it most likely to encounter a high concentration of hazardous ice crystals?

options.text: Clear for the first 1500 NM or so and then likely for the rest of the cruise.
It is NOT expected to encounter a high concentration at cruising altitude on this route.
At cruising altitude for the first 600 NM after initial climb.
At cruising altitude for the last 600 NM before descent.

variant.question: Upon encountering freezing rain during a cruise flight, one of the possible actions to minimize the ice accretion would be to:

options.text: climb to the warmer air above.
accelerate.
descend to a lower altitude.
climb to the cooler air above.

variant.question: What clue, during flight, can help pilots identify that they are flying into an area in which ice accretion may be encountered?

options.text: Rain with a negative outside air temperature.
Ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere.
The onset of Clear Air Turbulence.
The appearance of Cirrus clouds.

variant.question: Which of the following is the correct procedure for using the weather radar to detect and avoiding Ice Crystal Icing (ICI)?

options.text: Locate the main cell and fly upwind.
Climb over the top of the active cells.
Locate the main cell and fly downwind.
Penetrate the cloud using the weather radar to avoid active areas.

variant.question:
An area where rain ice is likely to be encountered must be avoided
An example of such area would be when flying

options.text: ahead of a warm front with the OAT gauge reading -5°C.
through an active cold front.
in the warm sector of a frontal depression during winter.
in a polar maritime airstream behind a cold front.

variant.question: Ice crystals,are often found in and around the anvil of a thunderstorm,What hazard do these present to an aircraft if found in high densities at very low temperatures?

options.text: The crystals can accumulate inside the engine, then break away, causing a sudden loss of thrust, especially at low power settings.
Because of their size, in high densities the crystals can reflect and block propagated satellite communication and navigation signals.
The crystals can accumulate on the wing and tailplane leading edges, reducing lift and increasing drag.
The crystals can accumulate on the aircraft's communication and navigation antenna systems and affect transmission and reception.

variant.question: How can you avoid areas with a high concentration of ice crystals?

options.text: Think ahead of the areas where ICI (Ice Crystal Icing) can be expected and avoid thunderstorms in the upwind direction.
Avoid the Cb.
Climb above the area where Ice Crystal Icing is expected.
Think ahead of the areas where ICI (Ice Crystal Icing) can be expected and avoid thunderstorms in the downwind direction.

variant.question: Which of the following describes cloud Ice Water Content (IWC)?

options.text: The IWC is measured in g/m^3 ^  and it reaches maximum values in the upper levels of the core of convective systems.
The IWC is a ratio of the liquid water to ice water within clouds and it increases with temperature.
As altitude increases within a convective cloud the IWC decreases, with the lowest values found in the anvil.
IWC is defined as the cloud ice volume per unit mass of atmosphere and the highest densities are found within Cirrus clouds.

variant.question: In order to avoid ice crystal icing, you should fly (1) ___ and avoid flying (2) ___.

options.text: (1) above the tropopause; (2) through or upwind of the anvil of a CB
(1) below the tropopause; (2) through or downwind of the anvil of a CB
(1) below the tropopause; (2) in high stratiform clouds near a warm front
(1) above the tropopause; (2) in high stratiform clouds near a warm front

variant.question: What is Ice Crystal Icing (ICI)?

options.text: Ice crystal icing is a threat for the engines at high altitudes (in cruise).
Ice crystal icing occurs when snowflakes and super cooled droplets mix and form rime ice.
Ice crystal icing is the reason for several engine failures below 10000 ft in the past years.
Ice crystal icing is a threat for the airframe at high altitudes (in cruise).

variant.question: What is Ice Crystal Icing (ICI)?

options.text: Ice crystal icing is a threat for the engines at high altitudes (in cruise).
Ice crystal icing occurs when snowflakes and super cooled droplets mix and form rime ice.
Ice crystal icing is the reason for several engine failures below 10 000 ft in the past years.
Ice crystal icing is a threat for the airframe at high altitudes (in cruise).

variant.question: Although hazardous ice crystals do NOT appear on an aircraft's weather radar, pilots can avoid most of these concentrations in flight by...

options.text: using the weather radar to identify and avoid CBs and the areas downwind of them.
looking ahead and spotting the crystal concentrations visually.
consulting the WAFC Significant Weather Chart, which have specific markings for forecast areas of ice crystals.
requesting ATC to vector them around the areas of ice crystal concentration that appear on ground-based radar.

variant.question: Which of the following atmospheric processes can lead to high ice crystal concentrations and ice crystal icing?

options.text: Strong convective activity lifting large concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where sublimation then creates very small ice crystals
Strong up-currents that allow large ice crystals to develop through collision and coalescence from small ice crystals
Large amounts of condensation in a convective storm producing large water droplets which then freeze into large snowflakes in the upper levels of clouds
Weak convection concentrates moisture in the lower parts of clouds where condensation creates small supercooled water droplets or ice crystals

variant.question: Which conditions are the best to create ice crystal icing?

options.text: 60 min

variant.question: Which conditions are the best to create ice crystal icing?

options.text: Convective cloud with high vertical extent such as a Cumulonimbus containing a high cloud ice water content.
The most hazardous Ice Crystal Icing conditions can be found in Nimbostratus clouds.
Ice Crystal Icing conditions can be found anywhere, even at lower levels, as long as the cloud temperature is below the freezing level.
Ice Crystal Icing is very dangerous when flying large Cirrostratus clouds as they are entirely made of ice crystals.

variant.question: An aircraft in the cruise is flying in stratiform cloud that covers an extensive area at the minimum safe altitude. If icing conditions are experienced, the best solution to avoid ice accretion is to...

options.text: climb to a higher flight level.
reduce the power setting.
select a new track.
increase the speed.

variant.question: During the cruise in an active convective area, the air traffic controller passes a report from an aeroplane ahead that they have recently passed through a zone of intense ice crystal concentrations. The reporting aeroplane is at a similar flight level and following the same route as the aeroplane behind. What possible hazard might this pose for the crew of the jet aeroplane behind as they half through the same area?

options.text: Unusual engine indications.
Heavy mixed ice on the forward-facing parts of the airframe.
Formation of clear ice on the forward windscreens.
Radio signal and navigational system errors.

variant.question: Where can you find the highest concentration of ice crystals?

options.text: Within the anvil of a CB.
At low altitudes in the vicinity of CBs.
In the top part of NS clouds.
At normal cruising level.

variant.question: What creates Ice Crystal Icing?

options.text: Sublimation of ice mostly in the top part of a Cb cloud.
Ice crystal icing is created when vapor hits below 0°C surfaces.
Impact with cold surfaces.
Ice crystal icing is most present in Ns clouds at very low temperatures.

variant.question: At the pre-flight planning stage of an IFR flight, the pilot notes a warm front is located between the aerodrome of departure and the destination. Of the options below, which is the best way to navigate in order to minimise any ice accretion associated with the front? (It is not possible to fly over the front for performance reasons).

options.text: Fly the shortest route through the front.
Orbit at the edge of the front and wait for an improvement.
Fly along the front to find a clear area.
Descend as low as possible while remaining above 500 ft AGL, below MSA in IMC if necessary, to pass under the front.

variant.question: At the pre-flight planning stage of an IFR flight, the pilot notes a warm front is located between the aerodrome of departure and the destination. Of the options below, which is the best way to navigate in order to minimise any ice accretion associated with the front? (It is not possible to fly over the front for performance reasons).

options.text: Fly the shortest route through the front
Orbit at the edge of the front and wait for an improvement
Fly along the front to find a clear area
Descend as low as possible while remaining above 500 ft AGL, below MSA in IMC if necessary, to pass under the front

variant.question: What is the definition of "ice water content" (IWC)?

options.text: Ice mass per unit volume of air.
Ratio of air quantity and volume of ice present in the air.
Ice mass per unit mass of air
Ice volume per unit volume of air.

variant.question: The type of icing that occurs in dense clouds with large supercooled drops that have a temperature of -5 °C is most likely to be:

options.text: clear ice.
cloudy ice.
hoar frost.
rime ice.

variant.question: Which of the following answers is true about clear icing?

options.text: During the freezing process latent heat is released which delays the freezing of the remaining liquid part of the droplet and makes it easier for it to flow back on the wing.
In this type of ice a lot of air is trapped between the ice layer and the aircraft surface.
This type of ice is not transparent.
Latent heat is released which expedites the freezing of the remaining liquid part of the droplet.

variant.question: Which cloud has the highest content of ice crystals that can induce in-flight engine power loss?

options.text: Cb
Ns
Cs
Ac

variant.question: Which cloud has the highest content of ice crystals that can induce in-flight engine power loss?

options.text: Cumulonimbus (Cb)
Altocumulus (Ac)
Cirrostratus (Cs)
Nimbostratus (Ns)

variant.question: Which one of the following statements is true about Ice Crystal Icing?

options.text: Ice crystal icing forms at high altitudes and is usually associated with the anvil of a Cb. A high accumulation of ice crystals can damage the engine and even cause engine failure.
Ice crystal icing forms at low altitudes and is usually associated with a Cb. It can affect all aircraft.
Ice crystal icing events are still under investigation and cloud avoidance is required.
Ice crystals are not very likely to form ice. Ice crystals need a nucleus to form, which is hardly found at high altitudes.

variant.question: What creates ice crystal icing?

options.text: Sublimation of ice with regards to CB clouds.
It is most present in NS clouds at very low temperatures.
Impact with cold surfaces.
It is created when vapour hits below 0°C surfaces

variant.question: High ice crystal concentrations and ice crystal icing is usually the result of:

options.text: Strong convective activity lifting large concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where sublimation then creates very small ice crystals.
Strong up-currents that allow large ice crystals to develop through collision and coalescence from small ice crystals.
Large amounts of condensation in a convective storm producing large water droplets which then freeze into large snowflakes in the upper levels of clouds.
Weak convection concentrates moisture in the lower parts of clouds where condensation creates small supercooled water droplets or ice crystals.

variant.question: Why is frost considered hazardous to flight?

options.text: All of the above.
Frost decreases control effectiveness.
The increased weight requires a greater take-off distance.
Frost causes early airflow separation resulting in a loss of lift.

variant.question: Describe ice crystal icing...

options.text: Ice crystal icing forms at high altitudes and is usually associated with the anvil of a Cb. A high accumulation of ice crystals can damage the engine and even cause engine failure.
Ice crystals are not very likely to form ice. Ice crystals need a nucleus to form, which is hardly found at high altitudes.
Ice crystal icing events are still under investigation and cloud avoidance is required.
Ice crystal icing forms at low altitudes and is usually associated with a Cb. It can affect all aircraft.

variant.question: In what range of temperatures will there be significant quantities of both ice crystals and liquid water droplets?

options.text: Minus 15ºC to minus 40ºC
Minus 40°C to minus 55°C
0ºC to minus 15°C
Minus 45°C to minus 75°C

variant.question:
(Refer to image) 
On which of these routes would you not need to worry about icing at FL 170?

options.text: London - Stockholm
Zurich - Athens
Paris - Lisbon
Madrid - Vienna

variant.question: One of the most serious consequences of icing on the wings of an aircraft is?

options.text: The stalling speed increasing substantially.
Lift becoming too great as the aircraft becomes heavier.
The wing construction being unable to bear the increased load.
The lift coefficient increasing as the aircraft becomes heavier.
